class_notes:
This course is designed to help you read, interpret, and understand some of the major literary works of the classical "canon" (stretching from the 8th century BCE epics of Homer to the works of Imperial Rome) from literary, historical, ideological, and comparative perspectives. The course will also help you develop critical thinking skills that can be applied to your other courses, regardless of subject matter.
The term "canon" may be problematic; yet, if one reads these texts closely and better appreciates their multifaceted nature, more substantial critiques and alternative perspectives can be offered. Through your close reading and discussion, you will eventually be able to ask fundamental questions, such as: What makes the classical canon a canon? How are those works relevant for our world? Why should (or shouldn't) one read these texts?
course_description: This reading-intensive class introduces students to some of the major authors, works, and genres of the classical canon, stretching from the 8th century BC epics of Homer to the works of Imperial Rome. We will wrestle with the major themes and concerns of a variety of ancient poetic and prose texts.
